markdownRemark.html:
Hey, it’s been a long time since I’ve written a blog. Here I’ll write a bit about technology, music, gaming, cities, and other personal interests.

For this site, I’ve decided to try out Gatsby.js, a static site generator for React. In this post, I’ll talk about my favorite things about Gatsby so far.

Write Posts Using Markdown

Eventually I plan for this site to be more like a webapp, so it’s convenient to be able to write a post using my code editor. Gatsby has a variety of plugins and transformers, one of which reads a directory structure of markdown files and compiles them to HTML output. To create a new post, I simply create a new directory under “pages” and place an index.md file in it. The name of the directory becomes the slug used in the URL, and the markdown file is rerendered in the browser instantly when I save the file in my editor.

Syntax Highlighting

The starter blog comes with prismjs, which adds syntax highlighting for code snippets and has support for dozens of languages and themes.
I chose the Okaidia theme and imported the CSS like so:

require("prismjs/themes/prism-okaidia.css")
Python
def hello(self):
    print "world"
    return True
PHP
<?php
function hello() {
    return "World";
}
?>
JavaScript
const hello = (hi) => {
    return "world";
}
Java
public class HelloWorld {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println("Hello, World");
    }

}

Modern JavaScript

Hot reloading, components, asset pipeline on top of Webpack and Babel. more like an app.

Starters and Themes

Deploy to Github Pages

No server here.

npm install gh-pages --save-dev

Then add following line in package.json

    "deploy": "gatsby build && gh-pages -d public -b master"

Then just run the deploy command with npm and all the JS, CSS, and HTML will be compiled. 

npm run deploy

There are also some neat things with GraphQL.
